newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK marchers defy Beijing, mourn Tiananmen killings.
newsitem.headline: HK marchers defy Beijing, mourn Tiananmen killings.

text.p: More than 3,500 protesters, defying future ruler China, marched along the main street of Hong Kong on Sunday to mourn Beijing's 1989 bloody crackdown on student-led democracy campaigners.

They waved banners demanding China, which takes over Hong Kong in a month, release jailed dissidents, and some bore a coffin on which was painted "the butcher government will remain notorious for a million years".
A protest rally on the Sunday before the June 4 anniversary is traditional and this year's turnout was bigger than usual. Tens of thousands are expected at a candlelit vigil on the day itself.
Eight years ago when tank-led troops killed massed, unarmed students in Beijing, a million people, a sixth of Hong Kong's population, poured onto the streets in anger.
Now an advance guard of People's Liberation Army troops is already in barracks in Hong Kong, set for the June 30 handover and pledged to develop "a good image" of the force.

The march reflected public unease as Hong Kong entered its final month under British rule, spurred by a confidence vote from the money markets but still saddled with questions about future freedom under China's red flag.
Business morale in the territory of 6.4 million is at an all time high as Hong Kong counts down to historic changeover.

The territory wrested by military force and "unequal treaties" from the old Celestial Kingdom, will become a Special Administrative Region, retaining a capitalist way life, of the People's Republic of China.

Hong Kong's stock exchange Hang Seng Index of blue chip shares gained 341-points on Friday to notch a fresh record close of 14,757.81. Turnover was the second highest ever at HK$18.74 billion (US$2.42 billion).

"There is no doubt that sentiment is pretty strong heading into the handover," Howard Gorges, vice-chairman of South China Holdings, said. "It is beginning to look as though 15,000 to 16,000 is the target range for the handover."
Mixed weather, with sudden rain and sunshine, reflected the mingled emotions of Sunday's protesters who fear the march will be the last of its kind to be permitted.

But they vowed to make further annual protests, even if declared tabooo, despite a warning by China-anointed future leader Tung Chee-hwa to abandon such demonstrations and keep Hong Kong from becoming a base for "foreign subversion."

"It will not be the last time. Next year, the year after and the years after, we will continue to hold commemoration. As long as there is June 4 on the calendar, we will be here," said the organiser Szeto Wah, chairman of the Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movement in China.
Szeto also said Chinese people would not rest until the military crackdown which killed hundreds was "redressed."
"As long as there are Chinese in this world, June 4 will not be forgotten.. As long as June 4 is remembered, it will be redressed," he told the crowd at the start of the march.
The protesters, waving placards with words "Never forget June 4", demanded that China end single party rule and institute democracy.

The march ended outside the Xinhua News Agency, Beijing's unoffical mission in the territory, where demonstrators laid a wreath for the victims and put up a banner that portrayed the Goddess of Democracy, the State of Liberty-type sculpture the Tiananmen students erected.
Beijing has branded the Alliance subversive for its role in helping many dissidents involved in the mainland's democracy movement escape overseas.
